title: Trying to settle a Heloc in California...
question: I stopped paying a Heloc two years ago and the home was foreclosed one year ago, I received a letter from a collection agency owned by the bank (Union Bank) offering to settle the 52k for less, they wanted at least 16k but they may be willing to settle for 10k, my question are:
answers:
Settling a HELOC after foreclosure (assuming there is even actual liability - and in California there may or may not be, depending on many factors) for 20 cents on the dollar is probably a great deal for a bank/lender. If the borrower has other debts, bankruptcy may be something to look into as a way to avoid paying the lender any amount. Most "BK" attorneys, my firm included, offer free initial consultations for potential BK clients... thus, there is no reason not to seek the advice of at least one such local BK attorney.

- Paul

I think the other two gentlemen give you excellent advice. Unless and until you don't see a proposed settlement papers, do not send money. It is best to get it checked from a local attorney in your jurisdiction. The two gentleman who posted their comments seems very qualified attorneys in this regard.

I think I should make a few comments. Your settlement is unlikely to affect your credit scores one way or the other. The foreclosure and non-payment are already reflected in your credit scores and will be reported for 7 years.

You should consult a bankruptcy attorney before you settle the HELOC. Bankruptcy might be a better option for you especially if you have other debt. Frequently debtors are seen as better credit risks after bankruptcy than before. Good luck.

Your settlement should be memorialized in a written agreement which specifically states that the bank, upon receipt of the $10K or whatever agreed upon amount is releasing you for all other liability under the HELOC.

Your foreclosure last year and your unpaid HELOC for the past two years are most likely already on your credit report.

Regarding taxes, see a tax professional regarding your specific situation. Generally speaking, under the federal Mortgage Debt Forgiveness Tax Relief Act of 2007 (applicable till the end of 2012), you will not need to pay any income tax on canceled debt (which is the unpaid loan balance that is forgiven by lender) resulting from a foreclosure, short sale or deed in lieu of foreclosure if you as the borrower satisfy certain conditions for mortgage tax relief (e.g., principal residence, owned for at least 2 years, debt amount of $2 million or less).

For more general information on debt forgiveness, 1099-A, and 1099-C, see:

http://www.irs.gov/instructions/i1099ac/ar02.html

http://www.irs.gov/uac/Home-Foreclosure-and-Debt-Cancellation

There is also an IRS Publication 4681:

http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p4681.pdf
